node.text:
The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is home to more than 200 species of birds and is sacred land for the Gwich'in people—but it has never been in greater danger. On the Arctic Refuge Day of Action, learn more about this vast Alaskan wilderness and what you can do to help protect this critical habitat.

Join us in taking action to #ProtectTheArctic today: https://www.audubon.org/arcticrefuge

node.title: Why Birds Need the Arctic Refuge

node.text:
Did you know that the Boreal Forest is home to between 1-3 billion birds that nest in the region each year? Not only that: it’s a nature based climate solution, holding about 12% of land-based carbon reserves. Audubon is working closely with our chapters, members, and Indigenous partners to protect one of the largest intact forests left on planet Earth. 🌲

On #WorldMigratoryBirdDay, learn more about conservation efforts for North America’s bird nursery: audubon.org/borealforests

node.title: The Boreal Forest: A Bird Haven

node.text: Just in time for National Native Plant Month, we’re learning all about #PlantsForBirds with Audubon’s Dr. John Rowden (@johnrowden) and Christine Lin (@chrriscross)! Want to find the right native plants for your area? Check out audubon.org/plantsforbirds.

node.text:
Dr. Steve Kress, or “The Puffin Man” as some like to call him, found a way to bring Atlantic Puffins back to Maine four decades ago after the seabirds were nearly hunted to extinction. Hear the story behind Project Puffin (now known as the Seabird Institute) in this video.

Join the Seabird Institute to #SaveTheSeabirds and protect the places they need today: https://bit.ly/3ad8UFw

node.text:
We’re talking all things spring migration with Audubon’s David Ringer (@davidjeffreyringer) and Christine Lin (@chrriscross). 

Want to learn even more? Tune in to our next episode of “I Saw A Bird” next Wednesday (3/31) at 7 pm ET! RSVP here: https://bit.ly/3lS3XGC

node.text:
Did you know that the Great Lakes provide drinking water to 40 million people and its coastal habitats support more than 350 bird species? As climate change, coastal development, and invasive species threaten these communities and habitats, @audubongreatlakes is ready with a bold plan.

Our new report, Restoring the Great Lakes for Birds and People, uses science to pinpoint the highest-priority coastal regions for birds, water quality, and coastal resiliency—focusing conservation where it’s needed most. Learn more and join us on this journey: https://bit.ly/397ppSG

node.title: Protecting Birds in the Great Lakes

node.text:
The fierce and resilient Bald Eagle is a common sight today, but did you know the species was on the brink of extinction in the 1970s? Eagles recovered thanks to increased protections under the Endangered Species Act, but new rules would weaken it. 

Urge your members of Congress today to stand up for this critical law: https://bit.ly/3tjk9TH

node.title: How the Bald Eagle Made a Comeback

node.text: It’s not just wildlife that depend on the sagebrush steppe; so do people. Entire livelihoods, businesses, and cultures are tied to this Western ecosystem. But an invasive grass is spreading across millions of acres. See how it’s impacting ranches like @winecup_gamble_ranch, hunters, and the @shoshonetribe in this new video from @audubonrockies. Then, tell Congress to take action to support cheatgrass control and sagebrush habitat restoration: http://audubon.org/cheatgrass

node.text: Audubon’s Seabird Institute works to restore Atlantic Puffin and other seabird populations to islands off the coast of Maine. Each summer, a team of research assistants live and conduct research on these islands. Listen in to learn about this experience. Want to apply to become a research assistant? Visit https://www.audubon.org/seabirdsummer

node.title: Audubon’s Seabird Institute Summer Field Research Program

node.text: Niki loves dogs and plovers—but knows they need to keep their distance as breeding season is around the corner. Join her as she helps #ShareTheShore and protects Snowy Plovers on the West Coast! @sinceresugar

node.text: Swans made of broken glass and ceramic appear to fly out of a 20-foot mosaic on a corner in upper Manhattan—serving as both an inspiring addition to a community hit hard by COVID-19 and a sobering reminder that the species, after bouncing back from near extinction, is now threatened by climate change. Learn how artists Carlos Pinto (@pintocards) & John Sear created the 20-foot mural: https://bit.ly/2XL2dna #AudubonMuralProject

node.text:
2020 may have felt like a long year, but it was no different in terms of the amazing and important things we accomplished. Join us in taking a look back—and a look forward.

Sign up to advocate for the birds you love and the places they need to make 2021 even better: https://bit.ly/3mnAZx0

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society on August 20, 2021. May be an image of bird, nature and text that says 'Audubon FLORIDA STAFF'.

node.text:
When @audubon_fl shorebird coordinator Kylie Wilson (@khelene94) came across Least Terns nesting on South Lido Beach in June—where they hadn’t previously been—she knew it was going to be a busy summer.⁠
⁠
From hurricanes to fireworks, banding chicks to moving colonies, Kylie sat down to talk more about her action-packed summer monitoring sea and shorebirds as a bird biologist for Audubon Florida. Given the breadth of her experience, she has plenty of wisdom on how beachgoers can leave a smaller footprint and #ShareTheShore with nesting birds. 🏖️⁠
⁠
To read the full interview with Kylie, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
1️⃣ - An Audubon staff member holding two banded Least Tern chicks. This photo was taken in compliance with state and federal research permits.⁠
2️⃣ - Kylie Wilson (right) and an Audubon volunteer band Least Tern chicks. This photo was taken in compliance with state and federal research permits.⁠

node.text:
Those aren’t snowflakes flurrying around this White Ibis—they’re thousands of tiny flying insects. 🪰 South Carolina bird photographer Kelley Luikey (@naturemuseimagery) is used to being swarmed and stung, but this time, they became part of the scene while shooting one afternoon in early March.⁠
⁠
Kelley arrived at one of her favorite rookeries, set up her camera, and took a peek in the viewfinder to find thousands of bugs backlit and framed by the glowing red samaras of a maple tree. Within a few minutes, a White Ibis landed on a branch, and Kelley framed it with the tree in the foreground and the horde of bugs floating all around.⁠
⁠
Her completed shot shows the White Ibis in brilliant white breeding plumage standing on the maple tree branch, its bright red legs and bill matching the red leaves. The thousands of bugs, backlit by the late afternoon sun, fill the frame like tiny sprites.⁠
⁠
Kelley’s enchanting photograph made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by National Audubon Society on August 19, 2021 tagging @melissagroo. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
⁠Social media is a boon for bird photographers. You’ve probably found that you can share your photos with a much larger audience and perhaps you can spark other people’s appreciation of birds with your work. But while there are plenty of best ethical practices to be aware of while photographing, there’s a whole other side of ethical considerations after you’ve taken your shot.⁠
⁠
For example, consider something as simple as deciding whether or not to post the location of your shot. Before publicly revealing the location of a bird—especially endangered or nesting birds—think about what kind of disturbance it could bring. A flood of visitors could wreak havoc on ecologically sensitive areas or disturb homeowners living nearby. As we build online birding communities, we owe it to the birds to ensure their protection comes first.⁠
⁠
On #WorldPhotographyDay, celebrate the craft of bird photography by learning how you can be a more responsible bird photographer in the digital age. Tap the link in our bio to find out how.⁠
⁠
A Great Gray Owl perched on a branch. 📷: Melissa Groo (@melissagroo)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in McKee-Beshers Wildlife Management Area with @julesjacobs_photo. May be a closeup of flower and outdoors.

node.text:
Be like this American Goldfinch and make sure you stop to admire the sunflowers every now and again. 🌻⁠
⁠
Jules Jacobs (@julesjacobs_photo) was admiring the sunflowers in the massive garden of the McKee-Beshers Wildlife Management Area, when he saw one of them unexpectedly start to move. This brilliant yellow American Goldfinch bounced from flower to flower, its feathers blending in seamlessly with the blooms, and its distinctive black cap and wings preventing it from being entirely camouflaged. This quiet moment in a sunflower field that’s usually crowded with tourists reminded Jules that with a soft footprint, humans can enjoy the beauty of places like this while preserving them for the birds that need them.⁠
⁠
Jules’s vibrant photo made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society on August 18, 2021. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
#BirdsTellUs we need to act on climate now. This week the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced 2022 will bring unprecedented water shortages to Arizona, Nevada and the Republic of Mexico—threatening the communities and wildlife that rely on Colorado River water supply. ⁠
⁠
“Historically, water management was based on the premise that drought would be followed by wet years. Climate change means we can no longer make that assumption. Good short-term solutions may not be sustainable,” says Jennifer Pitt, Audubon’s Colorado River program director. ⁠
⁠
As new operating rules for the river are crafted, it’s vital we heed the water rights of Native American tribes, invest in long-term strategies promoting the basin’s resiliency, and ensure that decision-makers don’t raid the last drops of water supporting Colorado River habitats. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the impacts of these water shortages on the Southwest and what can be done to ensure the plans in place to mitigate it are designed for the 21st century. ⁠
⁠
A Willow Flycatcher sings while perched on a branch. 📷: Susan Ward/Audubon Photography Awards

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by National Audubon Society on August 17, 2021 tagging @megan.s.bonham. May be a closeup of wading bird and nature.

node.text:
Sometimes our accidents end up being beautiful, like Megan Bonham’s (@megan.s.bonham) unconventional yet mesmerizing shot of a Sandhill Crane.⁠
⁠
When visiting Kensington Metropark’s unusually friendly crane population, two walked right past Megan. She knelt down and waited for them to approach, getting a traditional portrait as well as this self-described “screw-up” image of one of their heads taken from behind. That evening, as she reviewed the day’s photos, she found herself returning to this one over and over again, mesmerized by its textures. The Sandhill Crane’s red crown stands out against its blue-gray head feathers, its stubbly texture like a carpet. The bird’s right eye, just visible in profile, resembles a glass marble.⁠
⁠
Megan’s avant-garde shot made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by National Audubon Society on August 17, 2021 tagging @totemgraffx. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Meet TOTEM (@totemgraffx)—Washington Heights native, @nyphospital employee, and graffiti artist behind the latest installment of the #AudubonMuralProject. A graduate of NYC’s High School of Art and Design, TOTEM has built up quite the portfolio in aerosol art and has designed murals, canvases, and apparel. His latest addition? This White-tailed Hawk, located steps away from the hospital where he works.⁠
⁠
“I picked this bird because of its beauty and power,” he says, “so if you know my work, once you see it, you know it was me."⁠
⁠
With sharp eyes, broad wings, and powerful talons, the powerful raptor—native to the dry grasslands and coastal prairies of Texas—stoically welcomes visitors to the neighborhood. But our climate models suggest rising temperatures could force the bird out of its habitat. Like other murals commissioned for the Audubon Mural Project, TOTEM’s painting draws attention to a species threatened by climate change and adds vibrant new colors to the neighborhood he knows and loves. Being able to give back to his community in his own way—especially after the desolation of the pandemic’s early days—was a great source of pride for him.⁠
⁠
“I love animals and couldn’t pass this up,” TOTEM said in an interview with New York Presbyterian. “What we’ve learned from COVID is that we’re connected to nature and our environment in ways we never realized, so this was an important project for me given all we’ve been through.”⁣⁣⁠
⁠
TOTEM’s White-tailed Hawk mural is located on the corner of Broadway and West 164th Street in Washington Heights. For more about the species and the artist, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
1️⃣ - The artist, TOTEM, with his mural of a White-tailed Hawk for the #AudubonMuralProject.⁠
2️⃣ - A complete shot of TOTEM’s mural. ⁠
⁠
All 📷: Mike Fernandez (@mikefromperu)/Audubon⁠

node.text:
This Ring-billed Gull shows us why it’s important to show up on time—especially when your company is full of other uncompromising gulls. ⏰⁠
⁠
On a cold morning in Clifton, NJ, Siu Lau spotted hundreds of gulls resting on the water’s edge. This gull was looking for a spot to land and tried to squeeze in the middle of the colony even though there was no room. Readying his camera, he lined up the gulls with some trees in the background, laid down on the beach with the sun behind his back, and took a few photographs.⁠
⁠
The final photograph shows a mixed colony of gulls packed tightly together in the shallow water as the lone Ring-billed Gull hovers overhead, its yellow legs lowered and black-tipped wings fully extended, looking with its bright yellow eye for a place to land.⁠
⁠
Siu’s animated photo was included in this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society on August 16, 2021. May be an image of nature and tree.

node.text:
How do you know if you’re a ‘birder’? Do you need to have extensive knowledge about bird taxonomy, fancy equipment, and a flexible enough schedule to check out every rare or migrating bird in your area at the drop of a hat? The good news is: no, it doesn’t.⁠
⁠
In fact, anyone who enjoys watching birds should be able to call themselves a ‘birder,’ according to @birdability coordinator Freya McGregor (@the.ot.birder). Compared to ‘birdwatching’ and ‘birdwatcher,’ the terms ‘birding’ and ‘birder’ denote a certain level of expertise and competition that can alienate beginners. Instead, Freya suggests redefining birding simply as ‘the act of enjoying wild birds.’ This way, it doesn’t create an environment of exclusivity and helps us celebrate the multitude of ways people engage with birds on their own time.⁠
⁠
Read the rest of her essay on how this redefinition can possibly break down barriers in the birding community by tapping the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Binoculars and a lawn chair by the waterside. 📷: Lia Bocchiaro (@liabocchiaro)/Audubon⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by National Audubon Society on August 15, 2021 tagging @npprairiegrouse. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
As recently as 2017, the Attwater’s Prairie-Chicken was thought to be on the verge of extinction. After Hurricane Harvey clobbered Texas with disastrous flooding, biologists at the Attwater Prairie Chicken National Wildlife Refuge only counted 13 males in the wild. Since then, thanks to captive breeding programs in Houston and Glen Rose, that number has been steadily climbing. This spring, biologists counted 89 males roaming in the wild after 11 successful nests last year.⁠
⁠
Decades of research went into the effort to save the Attwater’s Prairie-Chicken, but only in recent years have the stars been perfectly aligned for the population to rebound. From 2018 to 2020, the captive breeding program reaped the benefits of mild weather and the eradication of fire ants from the refuge—an invasive species that feeds on insects prairie-chicken chicks rely on. The success of the program holds promise for the recovery efforts of other threatened grouse species. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the stunning return of the Attwater’s Prairie-Chicken and the years of work that went into it.⁠
⁠
Attwater's Prairie-Chicken in the middle of a courtship display, with orange air sacs on the side of its neck inflated, in the fields of the Attwater Prairie Chicken National Wildlife Refuge near Eagle Lake, Texas. 📷: Noppadol Paothong (@npprairiegrouse)⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by National Audubon Society on August 15, 2021 tagging @ericschertlerphotography. May be an image of grebe and nature.

node.text:
These three perfectly aligned Surf Scoters certainly made it easy for their photographer to follow the rule of threes. 📸⁠
⁠
While whale watching off the San Juan Island, Eric Schertler (@ericschertlerphotography) commanded his attention towards looking for the only Horned Puffin known to live in the Salish Sea. Unexpectedly, three Surf Scoters took off from the water and flew in a row past his boat. It took several tries to capture the birds in the frame as the boat rocked constantly, but Eric lucked out. He successfully captured the trio flying in a straight line across glassy blue water. The wing position of each of the dark birds is slightly different as they fly mere inches from the water’s surface in the center of the frame.⁠
⁠
Eric’s dynamic shot made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park with @countbogdan. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
Owl be frank—it doesn’t get much cuter than this trio of juvenile Barred Owls. 🦉⁠
⁠
Bogdan Alexandrescu (@countbogdan) had been observing a family of Barred Owls for some time. A few weeks after the owlets fledged, he noticed that they were seemingly inseparable, often perching in very close proximity. On this particular evening, the adults were running behind schedule with dinner, and all three owlets came racing in from different directions, nearly landing atop one another on a dead tree. In the few seconds before they dispersed, he had just enough time to balance his lens on a monopod and fire off a couple of shots at an aperture that captured all three in sharp focus.⁠
⁠
The three Barred Owls look as if they’re an extension of the tree itself. The front owlet looks directly forward, the middle owlet faces to the right, and the third looks to the left in front of a blurred background of leaves.⁠
⁠
Bogdan’s endearing photograph was featured in the #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list this year.
